linkTarget.anchoringText: At other times these areas were starved of coarse clastic material and blanketed by shale. Net reservoir thickness is generally less than 100 ft. and is expressed as a single loop or multiple loops on seismic. Analysis of reservoir data (logs, cores, and seismic information) indicate that the reservoirs in the field were deposited from lobate and distributive channel deposits to sinuous channel complexes with variable aggradations and/or lateral accretion as illustrated in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Depositional Framework of Dotun reservoirs and a seismic cross section showing the deeper producing intervals and shallow LTIFOs assessed during Ph4 study.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Depositional Framework of Dotun reservoirs and a seismic cross section showing the deeper producing intervals and shallow LTIFOs assessed during Ph4 study.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The W10 reservoir (Figure 2) is located south of the Dotun structure and overlies the shale above the producing U90 reservoirs. It is a single seismic loop reservoir and mostly below tuning (average net sand in main channel belt ~30ft). The reservoir consists of three NE-SW trending turbidite channel complexes named as Northern-, Central- and Southern- Channel Complexes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: W10 Top Structure Map showing NCC, CCC and SCC and infill wells (white circle) with GR log signature. The P1 producer (red circle) was drilled in the East and the W1 injector (blue circle) was drilled downdip in the West above an erosive channel. The figures on the right show the CCC extent (from new seismic) towards the East and probable source of aquifer water. The red dotted line shows the extent of the FDP seismic and model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: W10 Top Structure Map showing NCC, CCC and SCC and infill wells (white circle) with GR log signature. The P1 producer (red circle) was drilled in the East and the W1 injector (blue circle) was drilled downdip in the West above an erosive channel. The figures on the right show the CCC extent (from new seismic) towards the East and probable source of aquifer water. The red dotted line shows the extent of the FDP seismic and model.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: W10 Top Structure Map showing NCC, CCC and SCC and infill wells (white circle) with GR log signature.
The P1 producer (red circle) was drilled in the East
the W1 injector (blue circle) was drilled downdip in the West above an erosive channel

linkTarget.anchoringText: In absence of clear fluid contacts from the well observations, and pressure data from the aquifer, an OWC of 9091 ft. TVDss was used, based on amplitude shut-off analysis on the 2001 seismic, in the original FDP study. Facies distribution was carried out with established Electro-Facies scheme for Dotun reservoirs based on core data and log responses. The facies types included Channel Storey Axis (CSA), Channel Storey Margin (CSM), Inter-Channel Thin Beds (ICTB) along with Mud Rich Thin Beds (MRTB) or shale (Figure 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: shows the established E-Facies for Dotun reservoirs based on core data and log responses and the conceptual facies distribution variations in different deporegions. CSA represents coarse to medium grained massive sands deposited by high density turbidity currents in thalweg. CSM represents fine grained parallel to ripple laminated sands deposited from waning phase of turbidity currents. ICTBs are interlaminated very fine sand and mudstone beds with parallel, ripple, convolute laminations and deposited from dilute turbidity currents. MRTBs are laminated mudstone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: shows the established E-Facies for Dotun reservoirs based on core data and log responses and the conceptual facies distribution variations in different deporegions. CSA represents coarse to medium grained massive sands deposited by high density turbidity currents in thalweg. CSM represents fine grained parallel to ripple laminated sands deposited from waning phase of turbidity currents. ICTBs are interlaminated very fine sand and mudstone beds with parallel, ripple, convolute laminations and deposited from dilute turbidity currents. MRTBs are laminated mudstone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Water Breakthrough happened in the P1 well within six months of bringing the well on stream (Figure 4) and the water cut (WC) increased sharply to 50% within a few weeks. An interference test was conducted between the P1 and W1 wells to check for hydraulic connectivity. However, the pressure pulse from the W1 well did not reach the producer even after 2 days of monitoring, against the expected 1.3 days of transmission lag time based on theoretical calculations. Also, the composition analysis on water samples (Table 1) taken from the P1 well, showed that the produced water properties (salinity) are more consistent with the formation water than with the injected seawater.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: shows the Producer & Injector Well Performance till date

formatted-caption.caption-text: shows the Producer & Injector Well Performance till date

linkTarget.anchoringText: As shown in Figure 5, the Iteration 0 model yielded an improved history match specifically in a considerable aquifer influx scenario, but WBT was still roughly 1 year off. Also, it could not adequately replicate the BHP for both the P1 and W1 wells over the history period. This hinted that the model had better reservoir connectivity between the producer-injector pair than actually seen in the wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Iteration 0 HM outcome shows improved WBT with significant aquifer strength assumption but mismatch in WC rate, and BHP in the P1 and W1 wells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Iteration 0 HM outcome shows improved WBT with significant aquifer strength assumption but mismatch in WC rate, and BHP in the P1 and W1 wells.

linkTarget.anchoringText: It was inferred that because of the below tuning nature of the seismic and the presence of the aquifer, the reservoir amplitude in the area between the producer well and the aquifer in the East is not representative of the actual net sand distribution. Hence it was decided to carry out manual facies updates in this area based on conceptual models in an iterative manner till reasonable history match is achieved (described in Table 2 and Figure 6). Each realization yielded incrementally better history-matches (in terms of WBT & WC) than previous iteration. Iteration 6 had a better injector performance match, which was obtained by introducing flow barriers (Ibrahimov, 2015) between the producer and injector (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: shows Iterative Update of Facies Realizations within sector from Iteration 1 to Iteration 5

formatted-caption.caption-text: shows Iterative Update of Facies Realizations within sector from Iteration 1 to Iteration 5

linkTarget.anchoringText: It was inferred that because of the below tuning nature of the seismic and the presence of the aquifer, the reservoir amplitude in the area between the producer well and the aquifer in the East is not representative of the actual net sand distribution. Hence it was decided to carry out manual facies updates in this area based on conceptual models in an iterative manner till reasonable history match is achieved (described in Table 2 and Figure 6). Each realization yielded incrementally better history-matches (in terms of WBT & WC) than previous iteration. Iteration 6 had a better injector performance match, which was obtained by introducing flow barriers (Ibrahimov, 2015) between the producer and injector (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: shows introduction of baffle between the P1 and W1 wells to achieve a better injectivity match at the W1 location

formatted-caption.caption-text: shows introduction of baffle between the P1 and W1 wells to achieve a better injectivity match at the W1 location

linkTarget.anchoringText: For further improvement in HM, in-house processed "Lumina" seismic (higher frequency) was used to decipher a more detailed reservoir architecture, which showed two sand bodies: an older sand body (Unit1) overlain by a younger geobody (Unit2). A facies realization was built replicating the conceptual model (Figure 8). This iteration yielded significantly improved HM compared Iteration 6 across all key history match parameters as shown in Figure 9.
linkTarget.label: Figure 8

image-wrap.caption: a shows a flattened seismic section showing Unit 1 & 2 and the conceptual model is shown in Figure 8b. Figures 8c & 8d show the actual seismic section, and updated facies model, respectively.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a shows a flattened seismic section showing Unit 1 & 2 and the conceptual model is shown in Figure 8b. Figures 8c & 8d show the actual seismic section, and updated facies model, respectively.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For further improvement in HM, in-house processed "Lumina" seismic (higher frequency) was used to decipher a more detailed reservoir architecture, which showed two sand bodies: an older sand body (Unit1) overlain by a younger geobody (Unit2). A facies realization was built replicating the conceptual model (Figure 8). This iteration yielded significantly improved HM compared Iteration 6 across all key history match parameters as shown in Figure 9.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: shows Incremental Improvement in WBT & WC from iteration 1 to iteration 7 (scope for improvement). A good match was achieved in terms of BHP in the P1 and W1 wells.

formatted-caption.caption-text: shows Incremental Improvement in WBT & WC from iteration 1 to iteration 7 (scope for improvement). A good match was achieved in terms of BHP in the P1 and W1 wells.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 shows the final history matched realization and associated forecast for Iteration 7 post dynamic optimizations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: shows further optimization on the Iteration 7 static model, by implementing the DLGR method and applying a shallower contact. The orange line shows forecast from final HM realization.

formatted-caption.caption-text: shows further optimization on the Iteration 7 static model, by implementing the DLGR method and applying a shallower contact. The orange line shows forecast from final HM realization.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The study was carried out in Q3'16 based on only 4 months of post WBT production data and forecasted steady WC up to 2025 as pressure support around the producer well was expected to be maintained primarily by the active aquifer and the injector might indeed be redundant. The robustness of the HM exercise has been validated by actual well performance data (post study) from Sep'17 to Jan'17 (Figure 11) as forecasted from simulation. However, more production data and results from upcoming 4D monitor seismic are required for conclusive affirmation of our HM assumptions.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: shows good match between Prediction and actual Oil Rate (Violet) and WC (Green) post current HM exercise

formatted-caption.caption-text: shows good match between Prediction and actual Oil Rate (Violet) and WC (Green) post current HM exercise
